Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Documenting Sociolinguistic Variation in Diné bizaad (Navajo), a Native American Language

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Previous linguistic research has definitively demonstrated that an unvarying speech community is an idealization. In fact, linguistic variation is an important component of the documentation of a language. That variation frequently carries social meaning, often below the level of consciousness. This project documents and analyzes such variation as found in speakers' current usage of a Native American language. The Native American Languages Act, passed by the U.S. Congress in 1990, enacted into policy the recognition of the unique status and importance of Native American languages. Regional, generational, and sociocultural diversity are all factors in the diversity of a given language, but very little linguistic variation has been documented for this language. The documentation will form the core material analyzed in a doctoral dissertation produced by the CoPI. Broader impacts include recordings and descriptions of variation, of value for language planning and the development of pedagogical materials, and a publicly available deposit of the recordings and transcriptions at the Alaska Native Language Archive at the University of Alaska, Fairbanks, and locally at the Navajo Nation Historic Preservation Department.


Because much is already known about the sound patterns and word structure of Diné bizaad (Navajo), and due to the relatively large number of speakers, the language is a compelling candidate for a study of indigenous language variation. The CoPI, a doctoral student at the University of California, Santa Barbara, will record interviews including word lists, personal narratives, and ethnographic background questions with participants from different regions, of different ages, and with different linguistic backgrounds. The researcher will collaborate with a team of Diné bizaad speakers to transcribe and translate the discourse data for public archiving and in-depth analysis. These data will serve as the basis for an analysis of specific linguistic variants and how they correlate with social factors such as region, generation, and Diné bizaad usage. Through analysis of connected speech, this project will investigate morphological, syntactic, and discourse-level variation, and an acoustic analysis of targeted phonetic/phonological variables will provide evidence for ongoing sound change or sociolinguistically conditioned variation. Of particular interest is how speakers variably use Diné verbal morphology, which is famously complex. Sociolinguistic studies based on small indigenous communities are relatively rare, though extant studies suggest that such communities offer insights about socially meaningful patterns of variation. Further, this study will contribute to scientific understanding of language change by analyzing internally and externally motivated change at multiple levels of linguistic structure. It will also shed light on variation within the Athabaskan language family, which has figured importantly in theories of morphology and phonology, and which includes members in the Southwestern U.S., like Apache, as well as languages along the Pacific Coast, in Alaska, and in Canada.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examined sociolinguistic variation and language change in Diné bizaad (Navajo), a North American language spoken in the present-day American Southwest. The goals of this project included (1) creating an archived collection of different types of recorded speech that reflect the linguistic diversity of the bilingual Navajo-English speech community, (2) analyzing linguistic features in order to determine if specific variants are socially meaningful in the community, how linguistic innovations are developing, and speakers' attitudes towards variation and change, (3) using the project's findings to increase understanding of variation and change in an under-described sociolinguistic context.

            The data for this study were collected through fieldwork interviews conducted in 2016-2017 with 51 bilingual Navajo-English speakers representing different age groups, genders, and regions. The interviews included demographic background questions in English, a Navajo word list, an English word list, a retelling of a silent movie in Navajo, a personal story in Navajo, and a conversation in English about language attitudes and ideologies. The interviews were transcribed and translated, and the speech data were measured acoustically. Several linguistic features were annotated and quantitatively analyzed. These data are publicly accessible online through the Alaska Native Languages Archive interface under the collection title "Variation in Diné bizaad".

            This project produced several findings reported in the Co-PI's dissertation: (1) The Navajo language is undergoing sound changes that are spreading among younger speakers of the language. Navajo sounds that are phonologically similar to English segments were found to change; (2) These changes are motivated both by language-internal phonetic factors and by a high degree of English bilingualism. These results challenge assumptions about the singular role of language contact in driving change in these contexts; (3) This project contributes an analysis of a grammatical particle, an under-described, but productive area of Navajo grammar. The particle functions to mark past time and to connect events in discourse. These functions have likely developed from the particle's historical origins as a verb; (4) This project provides contemporary data on self-reported language usage and identifies generational continuity in ideologies towards variation. There is a strong perception of linguistic variation associated with region, language continues to be associated with family and culture even as the language is spoken less, and language shift is progressing with changes among younger speakers often negatively evaluated.

            Together the findings of this project inform theories of sociolinguistics and language contact, while contributing new data and analyses to be used in community efforts to support and maintain Navajo. The results show that though the language is changing in the speech of younger speakers, the changes are not all in the direction of convergence towards English, and the changes found are natural changes, not just the result of a breakdown in language transmission. These results draw attention to the diversity within the spoken Navajo language and the specific, innovative ways that the language continues to develop even in the face of intense pressure from English. The goal is that by drawing attention to variation present in the language, speakers will be more open to recognizing different variants in pedagogical materials used in language teaching. The project's data and results may be of interest now to Navajo linguists, teachers, and community members, and also in the future. The project's data are publicly available in order to expand the long-term impacts of the project. Finally, quantitative sociolinguistic studies, such as this project, are rarely conducted in minority indigenous language communities; instead the research has largely focused on larger global languages like English. There are practical and theoretical benefits to continuing to conduct these kinds of studies in smaller language communities, and it is the hope that this study can serve as a model for future work.
